SEG.ORIGINAL_TEXT: Court declares some GCHQ surveillance illegal

The Investigatory Powers Tribunal today released a judgment declaring that some aspects of GCHQ co-operation with the <b>NSA<b> (where the <b>NSA<b> spies on UK citizens and then shares that information with GCHQ) breached the human rights of the targets

I find this deeply troubling. I tend to reflexively support the security services and intelligence agencies. I think they do exceptionally important work, typically with no recognition outside their small community, and the IC is made up of some of the best people this country produces.

Having said that, as a law student I find unlawful activity on the part of security or intelligence agencies deeply concerning because they are given a somewhat greater degree of latitude and if they were ever to become corrupted, it would represent a significant danger to our democracy.

Ultimately, I think the most important thing is that the IPT has declared that the vast majority of GCHQ operations have been lawful and properly authorised, and the unlawful activity extended only to one small exception in a particular category of operations.
I agree with the OP. If preventing terrorists from blowing up your future Childs school for Jihad requires a little surveillance or torture.. Then so be it.

Any British citizen who reasonably thinks their communications were intercepted by GCHQ prior to December 2014 are now able to send a complaints form to the Investigatory Powers Tribunal in order to find out whether that was the case and demand to have the records deleted.
You can find the complaints form here <a rel="nofollow" href="http://www.ipt-uk.com/docs/FormT1_180614.pdf" target="_blank">here</a> ...

You've disappointed me on your point about a little torture. You're usually a voice of reason on this site. Torture as well as being dangerous to allow, is also no guarantee that people will fess up. People will fess up up anything when under physical torture.
There was a very good QT with paddy ashdown on torture, well worth a watch. I think it's about bin Ladin mostly.
You've disappointed me on your point about a little torture. You're usually a voice of reason on this site.

With regards to the unemployed, they should be provided with a travel pass and be banned from car driving until they have a job. The state should not have to listen to them say they can't afford food when they are blowing money on fuel.
Well I can at least see where he's coming from with that and I don't think it has anyway near the same risks as allowing torture.
I would rather families spend money on fuel than on booze, gambling ad fags at any rate.
"Privacy International today has launched a platform and campaign to allow anyone in the world to request whether Britains intelligence agency GCHQ has illegally spied on them.

The platform and campaign has been developed in response to a recent court ruling that GCHQ unlawfully obtained millions of private communications from the <b>NSA<b> up until December 2014. This decision allows not only British citizens, but anyone in the world, to ask GCHQ if the individuals records were unlawfully shared by the <b>NSA<b>."

"The regime under which UK intelligence agencies, including MI5 and MI6, have been monitoring conversations between lawyers and their clients for the past five years is unlawful, the British government has admitted.

The admission that the activities of the security services have failed to comply fully with human rights laws in a second major area this time highly sensitive legally privileged communications is a severe embarrassment for the government."

I think a lot of it revolves or should revolve around the way they are using the data. Intelligence and security services need it, and should do everything they can to stop terrorism etc. However a lot of the pass me downs to law enforcement are beyond dodgy.
